newsitem.title: USA: U.S. sees major gaps remaining on Mideast talks.
newsitem.headline: U.S. sees major gaps remaining on Mideast talks.

text.p: The United States said Friday that major gaps remained between Israeli and Palestinian positions as special envoy Dennis Ross returned from a mission aimed at reviving stalled peace talks.

"Significant work remains to be done between the Israelis and Palestinians. There are important gaps and divisions that remain between (their) positions," State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns said.

"But the United States is determined to keep at this and to keep these talks going so that we might find a formula to resume the political negotiations between Israel and the Palestinian Authority," Burns told reporters.

Ross was returning to Washington Friday after a three-day trip to the region for talks with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu -- now involved in a domestic corruption scandal -- and Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat.

He was attempting to revive talks that have foundered over a new Israeli housing project in traditionally Arab East Jerusalem. Palestinians have demanded that work stop on the project before they will resume the talks.
Burns described Ross's discussions as "very useful" but made clear that the U.S. envoy had never hoped to get the peace talks re-started immediately. "He had no such illusion," Burns said.
"He wanted to basically move them forward on the ideas that we have put on the table and on their own ideas," Burns added. But, he said, "we're still not there."
Burns said one success of the trip had been that Ross had managed to get Israeli and Palestinian security chiefs together with Arafat Thursday evening to discuss cooperation.
After his return Saturday, Ross is due to meet President Bill Clinton and Secretary of State Madeleine Albright to discuss next steps.
